{{short description|Late Bronze Age Greek culture}} {{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox archaeological culture |name = Mycenaean Greece |map = Mycenaean World en.png |mapalt = |altnames = |horizon = |region = |period = [[Bronze Age]] |dates = c. 1600 – c. 1100 BC |typesite = |majorsites = |extra = |precededby = [[Minoan civilization]] |followedby = [[Greek Dark Ages]] }} {{History of Greece}}
'''Mycenaean Greece''' (or the '''Mycenaean civilization''') was the last phase of the [[Bronze Age]] in [[Ancient Greece]], spanning the period from approximately 1600–1100 BCE. It represents the first advanced civilization in mainland [[Greece]], with its palatial states, urban organization, works of art, and writing system.<ref name=Fields-2004-10>{{harvnb|Fields|2004|pp=10–11}}.</ref> Among the centers of power that emerged, the most notable were those of [[Pylos]], [[Tiryns]], [[Midea (Argolid)|Midea]] in the [[Peloponnese]], [[Orchomenus (Boeotia)|Orchomenos]], [[Thebes, Greece|Thebes]], [[Athens]] in [[Central Greece]] and [[Iolcos]] in [[Thessaly]]. The most prominent site was [[Mycenae]], in [[Regions of ancient Greece#Argolis|the Argolid]], after which the culture of this era is named. Mycenaean and Mycenaean-influenced settlements also appeared in [[Epirus]],<ref>{{harvnb|Hammond|1976|loc=p. 139: "Moreover, in this area a small tholos-tomb with Mycenaean pottery of III B style and a Mycenaean acropolis have been reported at Kiperi near Parga, and another Mycenaean acropolis lay above the Oracle of the Dead on the hill called Xylokastro."}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Tandy|2001|loc=p. xii (Fig. 1); p. 2: "The strongest evidence for Mycenaean presence in Epirus is found in the coastal zone of the lower Acheron River, which in antiquity emptied into a bay on the Ionian coast known from ancient sources as ''Glykys Limin'' (Figure 2-A)."}}</ref> [[Macedonia (region)|Macedonia]],<ref>{{harvnb|Borza|1992|loc=p. 64: "The existence of a Late Bronze Age Mycenaean settlement in the Petra not only confirms its importance as a route from an early period, but also extends the limits of Mycenaean settlement to the Macedonian frontier."}}</ref><ref>[http://aegeobalkanprehistory.net/img_articles/thumbs/tmb_75.jpg Aegeo-Balkan Prehistory – Mycenaean Sites]</ref> on islands in the [[Aegean Sea]], on the coast of [[Asia Minor]], the [[Levant]],<ref>{{harvnb|van Wijngaarden|2002|loc=Part II: The Levant, pp. 31–124}}; {{harvnb|Bietak|Czerny|2007|loc=Sigrid Deger-Jalkotzy, "Mycenaeans and Philistines in the Levant", pp. 501–629}}.</ref> [[Cyprus]]<ref>{{harvnb|van Wijngaarden|2002|loc=Part III: Cyprus, pp. 125–202}}.</ref> and [[Italy]].<ref>{{harvnb|Peruzzi|1980}}; {{harvnb|van Wijngaarden|2002|loc=Part IV: The Central Mediterranean, pp. 203–260}}.</ref>
The Mycenaean Greeks introduced several innovations in the fields of engineering, architecture and military infrastructure, while trade over vast areas of the [[Mediterranean]] was essential for the Mycenaean economy. Their [[syllabic script]], the [[Linear B]], offers the first written records of the [[Greek language]] and [[Mycenaean religion|their religion]] already included several deities that can also be found in the [[Twelve Olympians|Olympic Pantheon]]. Mycenaean Greece was dominated by a warrior elite society and consisted of a network of palace states that developed rigid hierarchical, political, social and economic systems. At the head of this society was the king, known as [[wanax]].
Mycenaean Greece perished with the [[Late Bronze Age collapse|collapse of Bronze Age culture]] in the eastern Mediterranean, to be followed by the so-called [[Greek Dark Ages]], a recordless transitional period leading to [[Archaic Greece]] where significant shifts occurred from palace-centralized to de-centralized forms of socio-economic organization (including the [[Iron Age|extensive use of iron]]).<ref>{{harvnb|Morris|1996|loc="Greece: Dark Age Greece", pp. 253–256}}.</ref> Various theories have been proposed for the end of this civilization, among them the [[Dorian invasion]] or activities connected to the "[[Sea Peoples]]". Additional theories such as natural disasters and climatic changes have been also suggested. The Mycenaean period became the historical setting of much ancient [[Greek literature]] and [[Greek mythology|mythology]], including the [[Epic cycle|Trojan Epic Cycle]].<ref>The extent to which Homer attempted to or succeeded in recreating a "Mycenaean" setting is examined in [[Moses I. Finley]] ''The World of Odysseus'', 1954.</ref>
==Chronology== [[File:Lions-Gate-Mycenae.jpg|thumb|The [[Lion Gate]], the main entrance of the citadel of Mycenae, 13th century BC]] {{Main|Helladic period}}
The Bronze Age in mainland Greece is generally termed as the "Helladic period" by modern archaeologists, after ''Hellas'', the Greek name for [[Greece]]. This period is divided into three subperiods: The Early Helladic (EH) period (c. 2900–2000 BC) was a time of prosperity with the use of metals and a growth in technology, economy and social organization. The Middle Helladic (MH) period (ca. 2000–1650 BC) faced a slower pace of development, as well as the evolution of [[megaron]]-type dwellings and [[cist]] grave burials.<ref name=Fields-2004-10/> Finally, the Late Helladic (LH) period (c. 1650–1050 BC) roughly coincides with Mycenaean Greece.<ref name=Fields-2004-10/>
The Late Helladic period is further divided into LHI and LHII, both of which coincide with the early period of Mycenaean Greece (c. 1650–1425 BC), and LHIII (c. 1425–1050 BC), the period of expansion, decline and collapse of the Mycenaean civilization.<ref name=Fields-2004-10/> The transition period from the Bronze Age to the Iron Age in Greece is known as Sub-Mycenaean (c. 1050–1000 BC).<ref name=Fields-2004-10/>
{{multiple image | align = right | total_width = 320 | footer = Two Mycenaean chariot warriors on a fresco from [[Pylos]] (about 1350 BC; left) and two female charioteers from [[Tiryns]] (1200 BC; right) | image1 = Two Mycenaean chariot warriors on a fresco from Pylos about 1350 BC.jpg | width1 = 250 | height1 = 289 | image2 = Fresco of two female charioteers from Tiryns 1200 BC.jpg | width2 = 258 | height2 = 355 }}
==Identity== {{See also|Names of the Greeks|Achaeans (Homer)}}
The [[decipherment]] of the Mycenaean [[Linear B]] script, a writing system adapted for the use of the Greek language of the Late Bronze Age,<ref>{{harvnb|Chadwick|1976|p=617}}.</ref> demonstrated the continuity of Greek speech from the second millennium BC into the eighth century BC when a new script emerged. Moreover, it revealed that the bearers of Mycenaean culture were ethnically connected with the populations that resided in the Greek peninsula after the end of this cultural period.<ref>{{harvnb|Latacz|2004|pp=159, 165}}.</ref> Various collective terms for the inhabitants of Mycenaean Greece were used by Homer in his 8th century BC epic, the ''[[Iliad]]'', in reference to the [[Trojan War]]. The latter was supposed to have happened in the late 13th{{snd}}early 12th century BC, when a coalition of small Greek states under the king of Mycenae, besieged the walled city of [[Troy]]. Homer used the [[ethnonym]]s Achaeans, Danaans and Argives, to refer to the besiegers.<ref>{{harvnb|Latacz|2004|p=120}}.</ref> These names appear to have passed down from the time they were in use to the time when Homer applied them as collective terms in his ''Iliad''.<ref>{{harvnb|Latacz|2004|p=138}}.</ref> There is an isolated reference to ''a-ka-wi-ja-de'' in the Linear B records in [[Knossos]], Crete dated to c. 1400 BC, which most probably refers to a Mycenaean (Achaean) state on the Greek mainland.<ref>{{harvnb|Hajnal|Posch|2009|pp=1–2}}.</ref>
Egyptian records mention a ''T(D)-n-j'' or ''Danaya'' (''Tanaju'') land for the first time in circa 1437 BC, during the reign of [[Pharaoh]] [[Thutmoses III]] (r. 1479–1425 BC). This land is geographically defined in an inscription from the reign of [[Amenhotep III]] (r. circa 1390–1352 BC), where a number of Danaya cities are mentioned, which cover the largest part of southern mainland Greece.<ref name=Kelder4647>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|pp=46–47}}.</ref> Among them, cities such as Mycenae, Nauplion and Thebes have been identified with certainty. Danaya has been equated with the ethnonym ''Danaoi'' ({{lang-el|Δαναοί}}), the name of the mythical dynasty that ruled in the region of Argos, also used as an ethnonym for the Greek people by Homer.<ref name=Kelder4647/><ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|pp=37–38}}; {{harvnb|Latacz|2004|p=159}}.</ref>
In the official records of another Bronze Age empire, that of the [[Hittites]] in [[Anatolia]], various references from c. 1400 BC to 1220 BC mention a country named ''Ahhiyawa''.<ref name=BeckmanBryceCline4/><ref>{{harvnb|Latacz|2004|p=123}}.</ref> Recent scholarship, based on textual evidence, new interpretations of the Hittite inscriptions, as well as on recent surveys of archaeological evidence about Mycenaean-Anatolian contacts during this period, concludes that the term ''Ahhiyawa'' must have been used in reference to the Mycenaean world (land of the Achaeans), or at least to a part of it.<ref name=Bryce58>{{harvnb|Bryce|2005|p=58}}.</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Latacz|2004|p=122}}.</ref> This term may have also had broader connotations in some texts, possibly referring to all regions settled by Mycenaeans or regions under direct Mycenaean political control.<ref name=BeckmanBryceCline4>{{harvnb|Beckman|Bryce|Cline|2012|p=4}}.</ref> Another similar ethnonym ''Ekwesh'' in twelfth century BC Egyptian inscriptions, has been commonly identified with the Ahhiyawans. These Ekwesh were mentioned as a group of the [[Sea People]].<ref>{{harvnb|Bryce|2005|p=357}}.</ref>
==History==
===Shaft grave era (c. 1600–1450 BC)=== [[File:MaskOfAgamemnon.jpg|thumb|Death mask, known as the [[Mask of Agamemnon]], Grave Circle A, Mycenae, 16th century BC, probably the most famous artifact of Mycenaean Greece.<ref>{{harvnb|Burns|2010|p=92: "The most famous object from Shaft Grave V, if not all of Mycenaean Greece, is the gold mask popularly known as the "mask of Agamemnon"."}}</ref>]]
Mycenaean civilization originated and evolved from the society and culture of the Early and Middle Helladic period in mainland Greece under influences from [[Minoan civilization|Minoan Crete]].<ref name=Dickinson>{{harvnb|Dickinson|1977|pp=32, 53, 107–108}}; {{harvnb|Dickinson|1999|pp=97–107}}.</ref> Towards the end of the Middle Bronze Age (c. 1600 BC) a significant increase in the population and the number of settlements occurred.<ref name=Schofield31/> A number of centers of power emerged in southern mainland Greece dominated by a warrior elite society,<ref name=Fields-2004-10/><ref name=Dickinson/> while the typical dwellings of that era were an early type of [[megaron]] buildings. Some more complex structures are classified as forerunners of the later palaces. In a number of sites, defensive walls were also erected.<ref>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=51}}.</ref>
Meanwhile, new types of burials and more imposing ones have been unearthed, which display a great variety of luxurious objects.<ref name=Schofield31/><ref>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=48}}.</ref> Among the various burial types, the [[shaft grave]] became the most common form of elite burial, a feature that gave the name to the early period of Mycenaean Greece.<ref name=Schofield31>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=31}}.</ref> Among the Mycenaean elite, deceased men were usually laid to rest in gold masks and funerary armor, and women in gold crowns and clothes gleaming with gold ornaments.<ref>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=32}}.</ref> The royal shaft graves next to the acropolis of Mycenae, in particular the Grave Circles [[Grave Circle A|A]] and [[Grave Circle B|B]] signified the elevation of a native Greek-speaking royal dynasty whose economic power depended on long-distance sea trade.<ref>{{harvnb|Dickinson|1977|pp=53, 107}}.</ref>
During this period, the Mycenaean centers witnessed increased contacts with the outside world and especially with the [[Cyclades]] and the [[Minoan civilization|Minoan]] centers in the island of [[Crete]].<ref name=Fields-2004-10/><ref name=Schofield31/> Mycenaean presence appears to be also depicted in a fresco at [[Akrotiri (Santorini)|Akrotiri]], on [[Thera]] island, which possibly displays many warriors in [[Boar's tusk helmet]]s, a feature typical of Mycenaean warfare.<ref>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=67}}.</ref> In the early 15th century, commerce intensified with Mycenaean pottery reaching the western coast of [[Asia Minor]], including [[Miletus]] and [[Troy]], [[Cyprus]], [[Lebanon]], [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] and [[Ancient Egypt|Egypt]].<ref>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|pp=64–68}}.</ref>
At the end of the Shaft Grave era, a new and more imposing type of elite burial emerged, the [[Beehive tomb#Greece|Tholos]]: large circular burial chambers with high vaulted roofs and a straight entry passage lined with stone.<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=97}}; {{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=55}}.</ref>
===Koine era (c. 1450 BC–1250 BC)=== [[File:La Dame de Mycènes, fresco.jpg|thumb|Fresco depicting a female figure in the acropolis of Mycenae, 13th century BC]] The [[Minoan eruption|eruption of Thera]], which according to archaeological data occurred in c. 1500 BC, resulted in the decline of the Minoan civilization of Crete.<ref>{{harvnb|Chadwick|1976|p=12}}.</ref> This turn of events gave the opportunity to the Mycenaeans to spread their influence throughout the Aegean. Around c. 1450 BC, they were in control of Crete itself, including [[Knossos]], and colonized several other Aegean islands, reaching as far as [[Rhodes]].<ref>{{harvnb|Tartaron|2013|p=28}}.</ref><ref name=Schofield7172/> Thus the Mycenaeans became the dominant power of the region, marking the beginning of the Mycenaean 'Koine' era (from {{lang-el|Κοινή}}, common), a highly uniform culture that spread in mainland Greece and the Aegean.<ref>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=75}}.</ref>
From the early 14th century BC, Mycenaean trade began to take advantage of the new trading opportunities in the Mediterranean after the Minoan collapse.<ref name=Schofield7172>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|pp=71–72}}.</ref> The trade routes were expanded further, reaching [[Cyprus]], [[Amman]] in the Near East, [[Apulia]] in Italy and [[Spain]].<ref name=Schofield7172/> From that time period (c. 1400 BC), the palace of Knossos has yielded the earliest records of the Greek [[Linear B]] script, based on the previous [[Linear A]] of the Minoans. The use of the new script spread in mainland Greece and offers valuable insight into the administrative network of the palatial centers. However, the unearthed records are too fragmentary for a political reconstruction of Bronze Age Greece.<ref name="Kelder8"/>
[[File:Mycenaean armour 1400BC.jpg|thumb|left|Mycenaean [[Dendra panoply|panoply]], found in Dendra, Argolid, {{circa}} 1400 BC]]
Excavations at Miletus, southwest [[Asia Minor]], indicate the existence of a Mycenaean settlement there already from c. 1450 BC, replacing the previous Minoan installations.<ref>{{harvnb|Tartaron|2013|p=21}}.</ref> This site became a sizable and prosperous Mycenaean center until the 12th century BC.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|pp=50, 52}}.</ref> Apart from the archaeological evidence, this is also attested in Hittite records, which indicate that Miletos (Milawata in Hittite) was the most important base for Mycenaean activity in Asia Minor.<ref name="Bryce 2005 361">{{harvnb|Bryce|2005|p=361}}.</ref> Mycenaean presence also reached the adjacent sites of [[Iasos|Iasus]] and [[Ephesus]].<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|loc=p. 194: "The Mycenaean colonies in Anatolia were emphatically confined to a narrow coastal strip in the west. There were community-colonies at Ephesus, Iasos and Miletus, but they had little effect on the interior..."}}</ref>
Meanwhile, imposing palaces were built in the main Mycenaean centers of the mainland. The earliest palace structures were megaron-type buildings, such as the Menelaion in [[Sparta]], [[Lakonia]].<ref name="Kelder107"/> Palaces proper are datable from c. 1400 BC, when [[Cyclopean masonry|Cyclopean fortifications]] were erected at Mycenae and nearby [[Tiryns]].<ref name=Fields-2004-10/> Additional palaces were built in [[Midea (Argolid)|Midea]] and [[Pylos]] in [[Peloponnese]], [[Athens]], [[Eleusis]], [[Thebes, Greece|Thebes]] and [[Orchomenus (Boeotia)|Orchomenos]] in [[Central Greece]] and [[Iolcos]], in [[Thessaly]], the latter being the northernmost Mycenaean center. Knossos in Crete also became a Mycenaean center, where the former Minoan complex underwent a number of adjustments, including the addition of a [[Throne Room, Knossos|throne room]].<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|pp=108–109}}.</ref> These centers were based on a rigid network of bureaucracy where administrative competencies were classified into various sections and offices according to specialization of work and trades. At the head of this society was the king, known as [[anax|wanax]] (Linear B: wa-na-ka) in Mycenaean Greek terms. All powers were vested in him, as the main landlord and spiritual and military leader. At the same time he was an entrepreneur and trader and was aided by a network of high officials.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=11}}; {{harvnb|Fields|2004|p=53}}.</ref>
====Involvement in Asia Minor==== The presence of Ahhiyawa in western Anatolia is mentioned in various Hittite accounts from c. 1400 to c. 1220 BC.<ref name="Bryce 2005 361"/> Ahhiyawa is generally accepted as a Hittite translation of Mycenaean Greece (Achaeans in Homeric Greek), but a precise geographical definition of the term cannot be drawn from the texts.<ref name="BeckmanBryceCline6"/> During this time, the kings of Ahhiyawa were evidently capable of dealing with their Hittite counterparts both on a diplomatic and military level.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|pp=119–120}}.</ref> Moreover, Ahhiyawan activity was to interfere in Anatolian affairs, with the support of anti-Hittite uprisings or through local vassal rulers, which the Ahhiyawan king used as agents for the extension of his influence.<ref>{{harvnb|Bryce|2005|p=59}}; {{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=23}}.</ref>
[[File:14 century BC Eastern Mediterranean and the Middle East.png|thumb|upright=1.35|Eastern Mediterranean and the Middle East during the 14th century BC; Mycenaean Greece in purple]]
In c. 1400 BC, Hittite records mention the military activities of an Ahhiyawan warlord, [[Attarsiya]], a possible Hittite way of writing the Greek name [[Atreus]], who attacked Hittite vassals in western Anatolia.<ref>{{harvnb|Bryce|2005|pp=129, 368}}.</ref> Later, in c. 1315 BC, an anti-Hittite rebellion headed by [[Arzawa]], a Hittite vassal state, received support from Ahhiyawa.<ref>{{harvnb|Bryce|2005|p=193}}.</ref> Meanwhile, Ahhiyawa appears to be in control of a number of islands in the Aegean, an impression also supported by archaeological evidence.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=26}}.</ref> During the reign of the Hittite king [[Hattusili III]] (c. 1267–1237 BC), the king of Ahhiyawa is recognized as a "Great King" and of equal status with the other contemporary great Bronze Age rulers: the kings of [[New Kingdom of Egypt|Egypt]], [[Kassites|Babylonia]] and [[Middle Assyrian period#Middle Assyrian Empire 1392-1056 BC|Assyria]].<ref>{{harvnb|Bryce|2005|p=58}}; {{harvnb|Kelder|2010|pp=119–120}}.</ref> At that time, another anti-Hittite movement, led by [[Piyama-Radu]], broke out and was supported by the king of Ahhiyawa.<ref>{{harvnb|Bryce|2005|p=224}}.</ref> Piyama-Radu caused major unrest in the region of [[Wilusa]] and later invaded the island of [[Lesbos]], which then passed into Ahhiyawan control.<ref name=Kelder27>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=27}}.</ref>
The Hittite-Ahhiyawan confrontation in Wilusa, the Hittite name for [[Troy]], may provide the [[Historicity of the Iliad|historical foundation]] for the [[Trojan War]] tradition.<ref>{{harvnb|Bryce|2005|pp=361, 364}}.</ref> As a result of this instability, the Hittite king initiated [[Tawagalawa letter|correspondence]] in order to convince his Ahhiyawan counterpart to restore peace in the region. The Hittite record mentions a certain Tawagalawa, a possible Hittite translation for Greek Eteocles, as brother of the king of Ahhiyawa.<ref name=Kelder27/><ref>{{harvnb|Bryce|2005|p=290}}.</ref>
===Collapse (c. 1250–1100 BC)===
====Initial decline and revival==== [[File:Marching soldiers observed by a female figure, in a krater of c. 1200 BC in Mycenae.jpg|thumb|left|Marching soldiers observed by a female figure, in a [[Warrior Vase|krater]] of c. 1200 BC in Mycenae]] In {{circa}} 1250 BC, the first wave of destruction apparently occurred in various centers of mainland Greece for reasons that cannot be identified by archaeologists. In [[Boeotia]], [[Thebes, Greece|Thebes]] was burned to the ground, around that year or slightly later. Nearby [[Orchomenus (Boeotia)|Orchomenos]] shared the same fate, while the Boeotian fortifications of [[Gla]] were deserted.<ref name="Kelder 2010 34">{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=34}}.</ref> In the Peloponnese, a number of buildings surrounding the citadel of Mycenae were attacked and burned.<ref name="Cline 2014 130">{{harvnb|Cline|2014|p=130}}.</ref>
These incidents appear to have prompted the massive strengthening and expansion of the fortifications in various sites. In some cases, arrangements were also made for the creation of subterranean passages which led to underground cisterns. Tiryns, Midea and Athens expanded their defences with new cyclopean-style walls.<ref name=Castleden219>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=219}}.</ref> The extension program in Mycenae almost doubled the fortified area of the citadel. To this phase of extension belongs the impressive [[Lion Gate]], the main entrance into the Mycenaean acropolis.<ref name=Castleden219/>
It appears that after this first wave of destruction a short-lived revival of Mycenaean culture followed.<ref name=Freeman126/> Mycenaean Greece continues to be mentioned in international affairs, particularly in Hittite records. In c. 1220 BC, the king of Ahhiyawa is again reported to have been involved in an anti-Hittite uprising in western Anatolia.<ref name=Kelder33>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=33}}.</ref> Another contemporary Hittite account reports that Ahhiyawan ships should avoid [[Middle Assyrian Empire|Assyrian]]-controlled harbors, as part of a trade embargo imposed on Assyria.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=32}}.</ref> In general, in the second half of 13th century BC, trade was in decline in the Eastern Mediterranean, most probably due to the unstable political environment there.<ref>{{harvnb|Tartaron|2013|p=20}}.</ref>
====Final collapse==== None of the defence measures appear to have prevented the final destruction and collapse of the Mycenaean states. A second destruction struck Mycenae in ca. 1190 BC or shortly thereafter. This event marked the end of Mycenae as a major power. The site was then reoccupied, but on a smaller scale.<ref name="Cline 2014 130"/> The palace of [[Pylos]], in the southwestern Peloponnese, was destroyed in c. 1180 BC.<ref>{{harvnb|Cline|2014|p=129}}.</ref><ref name=Tartaron18>{{harvnb|Tartaron|2013|p=18}}.</ref> The Linear B archives found there, preserved by the heat of the fire that destroyed the palace, mention hasty defence preparations due to an imminent attack without giving any detail about the attacking force.<ref name=Freeman126>{{harvnb|Freeman|2014|p=126}}.</ref>
As a result of this turmoil, specific regions in mainland Greece witnessed a dramatic population decrease, especially Boeotia, Argolis and [[Messenia]].<ref name=Freeman126/> Mycenaean refugees migrated to [[Cyprus]] and the [[Levant]]ine coast.<ref name=Tartaron18/> Nevertheless, other regions on the edge of the Mycenaean world prospered, such as the [[Ionian islands]], the northwestern Peloponnese, parts of [[Attica]] and a number of Aegean islands.<ref name=Freeman126/> The [[acropolis of Athens]], oddly, appears to have avoided destruction.<ref name=Freeman126/>
====Hypotheses for the collapse==== {{See also|Bronze Age collapse|Dorian Invasion}} [[File:Invasions, destructions and possible population movements during the Bronze Age Collapse, ca. 1200 BC.png|thumb|Invasions, destructions and possible population movements during the collapse of the Bronze Age, ca. 1200 BC]]
The reasons for the end of the Mycenaean culture have been hotly debated among scholars. At present, there is no satisfactory explanation for the collapse of the Mycenaean palace systems. The two most common theories are population movement and internal conflict. The first attributes the destruction of Mycenaean sites to invaders.<ref>{{harvnb|Mylonas|1966|pp=227–228}}.</ref>
The hypothesis of a [[Dorian invasion]], known as such in [[Ancient Greek Mythology|Ancient Greek tradition]], that led to the end of Mycenaean Greece, is supported by sporadic archaeological evidence such as new types of burials, in particular cist graves, and the use of a new dialect of Greek, the [[Doric Greek|Doric]] one. It appears that the Dorians moved southward gradually over a number of years and devastated the territory, until they managed to establish themselves in the Mycenaean centers.<ref>{{harvnb|Mylonas|1966|pp=231–232}}.</ref> A new type of ceramic also appeared, called "Barbarian Ware" because it was attributed to invaders from the north.<ref name=Freeman126/> On the other hand, the collapse of Mycenaean Greece coincides with the activity of the [[Sea Peoples]] in the Eastern Mediterranean. They caused widespread destruction in Anatolia and the Levant and were finally [[Battle of the Delta|defeated]] by Pharaoh [[Ramesses III]] in c. 1175 BC. One of the ethnic groups that comprised these people were the ''Eqwesh'', a name that appears to be linked with the Ahhiyawa of the Hittite inscriptions.<ref>{{harvnb|Drews|1993|p=49}}.</ref>
Alternative scenarios propose that the fall of Mycenaean Greece was a result of internal disturbances which led to internecine warfare among the Mycenaean states or civil unrest in a number of states, as a result of the strict hierarchical social system and the ideology of the wanax.<ref name=Tartaron19/> In general, due to the obscure archaeological picture in 12th-11th century BC Greece, there is a continuing controversy among scholars over whether the impoverished societies that succeeded the Mycenaean palatial states were newcomers or populations that already resided in Mycenaean Greece. Recent archaeological findings tend to favor the latter scenario.<ref name=Freeman126/> Additional theories, concerning [[Bronze Age collapse#Nature and causes of destruction|natural factors]], such as climate change, droughts or earthquakes have also been proposed.<ref name=Tartaron19>{{harvnb|Tartaron|2013|p=19}}.</ref> Another theory considers the decline of the Mycenaean civilization as a manifestation of a common pattern for the decline of many ancient civilizations: the Minoan, the Harrapan and the Western Roman Empire. The reason for the decline is migration due to overpopulation.<ref>Andrey Alexakha A model of social progress. The journal of European economic history. (3) pp. 164-169. http://www.jeeh.it/articolo?urn=urn:abi:abi:RIV.JOU:2016;3.137&ev=1</ref> The period following the end of Mycenaean Greece, c. 1100-800 BC, is generally termed the "[[Greek Dark Ages]]".<ref>{{harvnb|Freeman|2014|p=127}}.</ref>
==Political organization== [[File:Mycenaean Palace States.svg|thumb|upright=1.45|Reconstruction of the political landscape in c. 1400-1250 BC mainland southern Greece]]
===Palatial states=== Mycenaean palatial states, or centrally organized palace-operating polities, are recorded in ancient [[Greek literature]] and [[Greek mythology|mythology]] (e.g., ''Iliad'', [[Catalogue of Ships]]) and confirmed by discoveries made by modern archaeologists such as [[Heinrich Schliemann]]. Each Mycenaean kingdom was governed from the palace, which exercised control over most, if not all, industries within its realm. The palatial territory was divided into several sub-regions, each headed by its provincial center.<ref name=Kelder9/> Each province was further divided in smaller districts, the ''da-mo''.<ref name=Kelder9/> A number of palaces and fortifications appear to be part of a wider kingdom. For instance, [[Gla]], located in the region of Boeotia, belonged to the state of nearby Orchomenos.<ref name="Kelder 2010 34"/> Moreover, the palace of Mycenae appeared to have ruled over a territory two to three times the size of the other palatial states in Bronze Age Greece. Its territory would have also included adjacent centers, including [[Tiryns]] and [[Nafplio|Nauplion]], which could plausibly be ruled by a member of Mycenae's ruling dynasty.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=97}}.</ref>
The unearthed Linear B texts are too fragmentary for the reconstruction of the political landscape in Mycenaean Greece and they do not support the existence of a larger Mycenaean state.<ref name=BeckmanBryceCline6>{{harvnb|Beckman|Bryce|Cline|2012|p=6}}.</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|pp=8–9}}.</ref> On the other hand, contemporary Hittite and Egyptian records suggest the presence of a single state under a "Great King".<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|pp=45, 86, 107}}.</ref> Alternatively, based on archaeological data, some sort of confederation among a number of palatial states appears to be possible.<ref name=BeckmanBryceCline6/> If some kind of united political entity existed, the dominant center was probably located in Thebes or in Mycenae, with the latter state being the most probable center of power.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|pp=86–87}}.</ref>
===Society and administration===
The Neolithic agrarian village (6000 BC) constituted the foundation of Bronze Age political culture in Greece.<ref>{{harvnb|Thomas|1995|p=350}}.</ref> The vast majority of the preserved Linear B records deal with administrative issues and give the impression that Mycenaean palatial administration was highly uniform with the use of the same language, terminology, system of taxation and distribution.<ref name=Kelder8>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=8}}.</ref><ref name=Kelder9>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=9}}.</ref> Considering this sense of uniformity, the [[Pylos]] archive, which is the best preserved one in the Mycenaean world, is generally taken as a representative one.<ref name=Kelder8/>
The state was ruled by a king, the ''[[anax|wanax]]'' (ϝάναξ), whose role was religious and perhaps also military and judicial.<ref name="Chadwick">{{harvnb|Chadwick|1976|loc=Chapter 5: Social Structure and Administrative System, pp. 69–83}}.</ref> The wanax oversaw virtually all aspects of palatial life, from religious feasting and offerings to the distribution of goods, craftsmen and troops.<ref name=Kelder11>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=11}}.</ref> Under him was the ''lāwāgetas'' ("the leader of the people"), whose role appears mainly religious. His activities possibly overlap with the wanax and is usually seen as the second-in-command.<ref name=Kelder11/> Both wanax and lāwāgetas were at the head of a military aristocracy known as the ''eqeta'' ("companions" or "followers").<ref name="Chadwick"/><ref>{{harvnb|Fields|2004|p=57}}</ref> The land possessed by the wanax is usually the ''témenos'' (te-me-no). There is also at least one instance of a person, [[Enkhelyawon]], at Pylos, who appears titleless in the written record but whom modern scholars regard as probably a king.<ref name=Chadwick71-72>{{harvnb|Chadwick|1976}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=RMj7M_tGaNMC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA71#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 71–72].</ref>
A number of local officials positioned by the wanax appear to be in charge of the districts, such as ''ko-re-te'' (''koreter'', '"governor"), ''po-ro-ko-re-te'' (''prokoreter'', "deputy") and the ''da-mo-ko-ro'' (''damokoros'', "one who takes care of a damos"), the latter probably being appointed to take charge of the commune. A council of elders was chaired, the ''ke-ro-si-ja'' (cf. γερουσία, ''gerousía''). The ''basileus'', who in latter Greek society was the name of the king, refers to communal officials.<ref name="Chadwick"/>
In general, Mycenaean society appears to have been divided into two groups of free men: the king's entourage, who conducted administrative duties at the palace, and the people, ''[[wikt:δῆμος|da-mo]]''<ref>{{LSJ|dh{{=}}mos|δῆμος|ref|mLSJ}}.</ref> These last were watched over by royal agents and were obliged to perform duties for and pay taxes to the palace.<ref name="Chadwick"/> Among those who could be found in the palace were well-to-do high officials, who probably lived in the vast residences found in proximity to Mycenaean palaces, but also others, tied by their work to the palace and not necessarily better off than the members of the ''da-mo'', such as craftsmen, farmers, and perhaps merchants. Occupying a lower rung of the social ladder were the slaves, ''do-e-ro'', ([[cf.]] {{lang|grc|δοῦλος}}, ''doúlos'').<ref>{{LSJ|dou{{=}}los1|δοῦλος|ref}}</ref> These are recorded in the texts as working either for the palace or for specific deities.<ref name="Chadwick"/>
==Economy== [[File:Mycenaean palace amphora, found in the Argolid, in the National Archaeological Museum in Athens.jpg|thumb|[[Mycenaean palace amphora with octopus (NAMA 6725)|Mycenaean palace amphora]], found in the Argolid]] [[File:Mycenaean stirrup vase Louvre AO19201.jpg|thumb|Mycenaean stirrup vase found in the acropolis of [[Ugarit]], Eastern Mediterranean (c. 1400–1300 BC)]]
===Organization=== The Mycenaean economy, given its pre-monetary nature, was focused on the redistribution of goods, commodities and labor by a central administration. The preserved Linear B records in Pylos and Knossos indicate that the palaces were closely monitoring a variety of industries and commodities, the organization of land management and the rations given to the dependent personnel.<ref name=Olsen7>{{harvnb|Olsen|2014|p=7}}.</ref><ref name=Cline145/> The Mycenaean palaces maintained extensive control of the nondomestic areas of production through careful control and acquisition and distribution in the palace industries, and the tallying of produced goods.<ref name=Cline242>{{harvnb|Cline|2012|p=242}}.</ref><ref name=Budin94>{{harvnb|Budin|2009|p=94}}.</ref> For instance, the Knossos tablets record c. 80,000-100,000 sheep grazing in central [[Crete]], and the quantity of the expected wool from these sheep and their offspring, as well as how this wool was allocated.<ref name=Budin94/> The archives of Pylos display a specialized workforce, where each worker belonged to a precise category and was assigned to a specific task in the stages of production, notably in textiles.<ref>{{harvnb|Chadwick|1976|p=152}}.</ref>
Nevertheless, palatial control over resources appears to have been highly selective in spatial terms and in terms of how different industries were managed.<ref>{{harvnb|Olsen|2014|p=6}}.</ref> Thus, sectors like the production of perfumed oil and bronze materials were directly monitored from the palace, but the production of ceramics was only indirectly monitored.<ref>{{harvnb|Budin|2009|p=96}}.</ref> Regional transactions between the palaces are also recorded on a few occasions.<ref>{{harvnb|Tartaron|2013|p=24}}.</ref>
===Large-scale infrastructure=== The palatial centers organized their workforce and resources for the construction of large scale projects in the fields of agriculture and industry.<ref name=Cline145/> The magnitude of some projects indicates that this was the result of combined efforts from multiple palatial centers. Most notable of them are the drainage system of the [[Lake Copais|Kopais]] basin in Boeotia, the building of a large dam outside Tiryns, and the drainage of the swamp in the [[Nemea]] valley.<ref name="Kelder116">{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=116}}.</ref> Also noticeable is the construction of harbors, such as the harbor of Pylos, that were capable of accommodating large Bronze Age era vessels like the one found at [[Uluburun shipwreck|Uluburun]].<ref name="Kelder116"/> The Mycenaean economy also featured large-scale manufacturing as testified by the extent of workshop complexes that have been discovered, the largest known to date being the recent ceramic and hydraulic installations found in [[Euonymeia]], next to Athens, that produced tableware, textiles, sails, and ropes for [[export]] and [[shipbuilding]].<ref name="Gilstrap">{{cite conference|last=Gilstrap|first=William|last2=Day|first2=Peter|last3=Kaza|first3=Konstantina|last4=Kardamaki|first4=Elina|title=Pottery Production at the Late Mycenaean site of Alimos, Attica|conference=Materials and Industries in the Mycenaean World: Current Approaches to the Study of Materials and Industries in Prehistoric Greece, University of Nottingham, 9–10 May 2013|conferenceurl=https://www.nottingham.ac.uk/archaeology/documents/conferences/ahrc-conference-abstracts.pdf|place=Nottingham, UK|date=9 May 2013|pages=13–14}}</ref>
The most famous project of the Mycenaean era was the network of roads in the [[Peloponnese]].<ref name="Kelder116"/> This appears to have facilitated the speedy deployment of troops—for example, the remnants of a Mycenaean road, along with what appears to have been a Mycenaean defensive wall on the [[Isthmus of Corinth]]. The Mycenaean era saw the zenith of infrastructure engineering in Greece, and this appears not to have been limited to the Argive plain.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=117}}.</ref>
===Trade=== [[File:Earring Mycenae Louvre Bj135.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.9|Gold earring, ca. 1600 BC, Louvre Museum]] [[File:Megiste-Bronze Reconstruction of a Mycenaean ship.jpg|thumb|Reconstruction of a Mycenaean ship]] Trade over vast areas of the Mediterranean was essential for the economy of Mycenaean Greece.<ref name=Cline145/> The Mycenaean palaces imported raw materials, such as metals, ivory and glass, and exported processed commodities and objects made from these materials, in addition to local products: oil, perfume, wine, wool and pottery.<ref name=Cline145>{{harvnb|Cline|2012|p=145}}.</ref> International trade of that time was not only conducted by palatial emissaries but also by independent merchants.<ref name="Cline200"/>
Based on archaeological findings in the Middle East, in particular physical artifacts, textual references, inscriptions and wall paintings, it appears that Mycenaean Greeks achieved strong commercial and cultural interaction with most of the Bronze Age people living in this region: [[Canaan]]ites, [[Kassites]], [[Mitanni]], [[History of the Assyrian people#Ancient Assyria|Assyrians]], and [[Ancient Egyptians|Egyptians]].<ref name=Cline200>{{harvnb|Cline|2007|p=200}}.</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Stubbings|1951|loc=IV: Mycenaean II Pottery in Syria and Palestine; V: Mycenaean III Pottery in Syria and Palestine}}.</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Petrie|1894}}.</ref> The 14th century [[Uluburun shipwreck]], off the coast of southern Anatolia, displays the established trade routes that supplied the Mycenaeans with all the raw materials and items that the economy of Mycenaean Greece needed, such as copper and tin for the production of bronze products.<ref>{{harvnb|Cline|2012|pp=300, 387, 787}}.</ref> A chief export of the Mycenaeans was [[olive oil]], which was a multi-purpose product.<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=107: "Huge quantities of olive oil were produced and it must have been a major source of wealth. The simple fact that southern Greece is far more suitable climatically for olive production may explain why the Mycenaean civilization made far greater advances in the south than in the north. The oil had a variety of uses, in cooking, as a dressing, as soap, as lamp oil, and as a base for manufacturing unguents."}}</ref>
Cyprus appears to be the principal intermediary station between Mycenaean Greece and the Middle East, based on the considerable greater quantities of Mycenaean goods found there.<ref>{{harvnb|Tartaron|2013|p=29}}; {{harvnb|Kling|1989}}; {{harvnb|Nikolaou|1973}}; {{harvnb|International Archaeological Symposium|1973}}.</ref> On the other hand, trade with the [[Hittites|Hittite]] lands in central Anatolia appears to have been limited.<ref name=Cline200/><ref>{{harvnb|Cline|2007|p=197}}.</ref> Trade with [[Troy]] is also well attested, while Mycenaean trade routes expanded further to the [[Bosphorus]] and the shores of the [[Black Sea]].<ref>{{harvnb|Cline|2007|p=196}}.</ref> Mycenaean swords have been found as far away as [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] in the eastern Black Sea coast.<ref>[http://www.bu.edu/historic/hs/september02.html Boston University – The Historical Society].</ref>
Commercial interaction was also intense with the Italian peninsula and the western Mediterranean. Mycenaean products, especially pottery, were exported to [[Magna Grecia|southern Italy]], [[Sicily]] and the [[Aeolian islands]]. Mycenaean products also penetrated further into [[Sardinia]],<ref>{{harvnb|Tartaron|2013|p=22}}; {{harvnb|Feuer|2004|pp=155–157}}; {{harvnb|Balmuth|Tykot|1998|loc="The Mycenaeans in Sardinia", p. 400}}; {{harvnb|Runnels|Murray|2001|p=15}}.</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Ridgway|1992|p=4}}; {{harvnb|Taylour|1958}}; {{harvnb|Fisher|1998}}; {{harvnb|Runnels|Murray|2001|p=15}}; {{harvnb|Vianello|2005|loc="Eastern Sicily and the Aeolian Islands", p. 51}}; {{harvnb|Feuer|2004|pp=155–157}}; {{harvnb|van Wijngaarden|2002|loc=Part IV: The Central Mediterranean, pp. 203-260}}.</ref> as well as southern [[Spain]].<ref>{{harvnb|de la Cruz|1988|pp=77–92}}; {{harvnb|Ridgway|1992|p=3}}; {{harvnb|Runnels|Murray|2001|p=15}}.</ref>
Sporadic objects of Mycenaean manufacture were found in various distant locations, like in Central Europe,<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005}}.</ref> such as in [[Bavaria]], [[Germany]], where an amber object inscribed with Linear B symbols has been unearthed.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.kranznet.indi.de/brzeit/goldfund/bernstei.htm |title=Amber object bearing Linear B symbols |access-date=February 9, 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160830122309/http://www.kranznet.indi.de/brzeit/goldfund/bernstei.htm |archive-date=August 30, 2016 |location=Freising |year=1999 |language=de}}</ref> Mycenaean bronze double axes and other objects dating from the 13th century BC have been found in [[Ireland]] and in [[Wessex]] and [[Cornwall]] in [[England]].<ref>{{harvnb|Budin|2009|loc=p. 53: "One of the most extraordinary examples of the extent of Mycenaean influence was the Pelynt Dagger, a fragment of a Late Helladic III sword, which has come to light in the tomb of a Wessex chieftain in southern England!"}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Feuer|2004|p=259}}.</ref>
==Religion== {{See also|Mycenaean religion|List of Mycenaean gods}} [[File:Lady of Phylakopi, 14th c BC, AM Milos, B 655, 152499.jpg|thumb|upright|The Lady of Phylakopi; wheel-made pottery figurine of a goddess or priestess from the West Shrine in [[Phylakopi]]; [[Helladic period|late Helladic III A period]], 14th century BC, [[Archaeological Museum of Milos]]]] Temples and shrines are strangely rare in the Mycenaean archaeological sites. Monumental cultic structures are absent at all the palatial centers, with the exception of Mycenae. However, the cultic center of Mycenae seems to have been a later (13th century BC) development.<ref name=Kelder115/> Small shrines have been identified in [[Asine]], Berbati, Malthi and Pylos,<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=146}}.</ref> while a number of sacred enclosures have been located near Mycenae, [[Delphi]] and [[Amyclae|Amyklae]].<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=157}}.</ref> Linear B records mention a number of sanctuaries dedicated to a variety of deities, at least in Pylos and Knossos. They also indicate that there were various religious festivities including offerings.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=114}}.</ref> Written Mycenaean records mention various priests and priestesses who were responsible for specific shrines and temples.<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=144}}.</ref> The latter were prominent figures in society, and the role of Mycenaean women in religious festivities was also important, just as in [[Minoan civilization|Minoan]] Crete.<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=160}}.</ref>
The Mycenaean pantheon already included many divinities that were subsequently encountered in Classical Greece,<ref>{{cite web|last=Paul|first=Adams John|title=Mycenaean Divinities|location=Northridge, CA|publisher=California State University|date=10 January 2010|accessdate=25 September 2013|url=http://www.csun.edu/~hcfll004/mycen.html}}</ref> although it is difficult to determine whether these deities had the characteristics and responsibilities that would be attributed to them in later periods.<ref name=Castleden143>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=143}}.</ref> In general, the same divinities were worshipped throughout the Mycenaean palatial world. There may be some indications for local deities at various sites, in particular in Crete. The uniformity of Mycenaean religion is also reflected in archaeological evidence with the phi- and psi-figurines that have been found all over Late Bronze Age Greece.<ref name=Kelder115>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=115}}.</ref>
[[Poseidon]] (Linear B: ''Po-se-da-o'') seems to have occupied a place of privilege. He was a [[chthonic]] deity, connected with earthquakes (''E-ne-si-da-o-ne'': Earth-shaker), but it seems that he also represented the river spirit of the underworld.<ref>{{harvnb|Nilsson|1940}}.</ref> [[Paean (god)|Paean]] (''Pa-ja-wo'') is probably the precursor of the Greek physician of the gods in Homer's ''[[Iliad]]''. He was the personification of the magic-song which was supposed to "heal" the patient.<ref>{{harvnb|Nilsson|1967|loc=Volume I, pp. 500–504}}; {{harvnb|Chadwick|1976|loc=p. 88: "''Pa-ja-wo'' suggested Homeric Paieon, which earlier would have been ''Paiawon'', later ''Paidn'', an alternative name of Apollo, if not again a separate god."}}</ref> A number of divinities have been identified in the Mycenaean scripts only by their [[epithet]]s used during later antiquity. For example, ''Qo-wi-ja'' ("cow-eyed") is a standard Homeric ephithet of Hera.<ref name="Chadwick 1976 95"/> Ares appeared under the name ''Enyalios'' (assuming that ''Enyalios'' is not a separate god).<ref>{{harvnb|Chadwick|1976|pp=95, 99}}.</ref> Additional divinities that can be also found in later periods include [[Hephaestus]], [[Erinyes|Erinya]], [[Artemis]] (''a-te-mi-to'' and ''a-ti-mi-te'') and [[Dionysos]] (''Di-wo-nu-so'').<ref>{{harvnb|Nilsson|1967|loc=Volume I, pp. 565–568}}.</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Chadwick|1976|p=99}}.</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Chadwick|Baumbach|1963|p=176f}}.</ref><ref>Kn V 52 (text 208 in Ventris and Chadwick); {{harvnb|Chadwick|1976|p=88}}.</ref> [[Zeus]] also appears in the Mycenaean pantheon, but he was certainly not the chief deity.<ref name=Castleden143/>
A collection of "ladies" or "mistresses", ''Po-ti-ni-ja'' (''Potnia'') are named in the Mycenaean scripts. As such, [[Athena]] (''A-ta-na'') appears in an inscription at [[Knossos]] as ''mistress Athena'', similar to a later [[Homer]]ic expression, but in the Pylos tablets she is mentioned without any accompanying word.<ref name="Mylonas159"/> ''Si-to po-ti-ni-ja'' appears to be an agricultural goddess, possibly related to [[Demeter]] of later antiquity,<ref name="Chadwick 1976 95">{{harvnb|Chadwick|1976|p=95}}</ref> while in Knossos there is the "mistress of the Labyrinth".<ref>{{harvnb|Chadwick|1976|pp=92–93}}.</ref> The "two queens and the king" (''wa-na-ssoi'', ''wa-na-ka-te'') are mentioned in Pylos.<ref>{{harvnb|Mylonas|1966|loc=p. 159: "Wa-na-ssoi, wa-na-ka-te, (to the two queens and the king). Wanax is best suited to Poseidon, the special divinity of Pylos. The identity of the two divinities addressed as wanassoi, is uncertain."}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Chadwick|1976|p=76}}.</ref> Goddess ''Pe-re-swa'' mentioned may be related to Persephone.<ref name="Chadwick 1976 95"/><ref name="Mylonas159">{{harvnb|Mylonas|1966|p=159}}.</ref> A number of Mycenaean divinities seem to have no later equivalents, such as Marineus, Diwia and Komawenteia.<ref name=Castleden143/>
==Architecture==
===Palaces=== [[File:Tiryns, map of the palace and the surrounding fortifications.png|thumb|upright=1.15|[[Tiryns]], map of the palace and the surrounding fortifications]] The palatial structures at Mycenae, Tiryns and Pylos were erected on the summits of hills or rocky outcrops, dominating the immediate surroundings.<ref name=Fields19>{{harvnb|Fields|2004|p=19}}</ref> The best preserved are found in Pylos and Tiryns, while Mycenae and the Menelaion are only partially preserved. In Central Greece, Thebes and Orchomenos have been only partially exposed. On the other hand, the palace built at the [[acropolis of Athens]] has been almost completely destroyed. A substantial building at [[Dimini]] in Thessaly, possibly ancient [[Iolcos]],<ref>{{harvnb|Cline|2012|p=485}}</ref> is believed by a number of archaeologists to be a palace.<ref name=Fields19/> A Mycenaean palace has been also unearthed in [[Laconia]], near the modern village of Xirokambi.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ταράντου|first=Σοφία|title=Βρήκαν μυκηναϊκό ανάκτορο|publisher=Ethnos.gr|date=28 April 2009|accessdate=25 September 2013|url=http://www.ethnos.gr/article.asp?catid=22733&subid=2&pubid=3320805&tag=8777}}</ref>
[[File:Hearth of the megaron of Pylos.jpg|thumb|The hearth of the [[megaron]] of Pylos]]
The palatial structures of mainland Greece share a number of common features.<ref name=Kelder109>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=109}}</ref> The focal point of the socio-political aspect of a Mycenaean palace was the [[megaron]], the throne room.<ref name=Fields19/> It was laid out around a circular hearth surrounded by four columns. The throne was generally found on the right-hand side upon entering the room, while the interior of the megaron was lavishly decorated, flaunting images designed intentionally to demonstrate the political and religious power of the ruler.<ref>{{harvnb|Fields|2004|p=21}}</ref> Access to the megaron was provided through a court, which was reached from a [[Propylaea|propylon]].<ref name=Kelder109/> The iconography of the palatial chambers is remarkably uniform throughout Greece. For instance, in Pylos and Tiryns the paintings are focused on marine motifs, providing depictions of octopi, fish and dolphins.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=110}}</ref> Around the megaron a group of courtyards each opened upon several rooms of different dimensions, such as storerooms and workshops, as well as reception halls and living quarters.<ref name=Kelder109/> In general Mycenaean palaces have yielded a wealth of artifacts and fragmentary frescoes.<ref name=Kelder109/>
Additional common features are shared by the palaces of Pylos, Mycenae and Tiryns;<ref name=Kelder109/> a large court with colonnades lies directly in front of the central megaron,<ref>{{harvnb|Fields|2004|p=20}}.</ref> while a second, but smaller, megaron is also found inside these structures.<ref name=Kelder109/> The staircases in the palace of [[Pylos]] indicate that the palaces had two stories.<ref>{{harvnb|Fields|2004|p=45}}</ref> The private quarters of the members of the royal family were presumably located on the second floor.<ref>{{harvnb|Fields|2004|p=46}}</ref>
===Fortifications=== [[File:MicenePortaLeoniMura.jpg|thumb|[[Cyclopean masonry]] in the southern walls of Mycenae]] The construction of defensive structures was closely linked to the establishment of the palaces in mainland Greece. The principal Mycenaean centers were well-fortified and usually situated on an elevated terrain, like on the [[acropolis]] of [[Athens]], [[Tiryns]] and [[Mycenae]] or on coastal plains, in the case of [[Gla]].<ref name=Fields10/> Mycenaean Greeks in general appreciated the symbolism of war as expressed in defensive architecture, reflected by the visual impressiveness of their fortifications.<ref name=Fields10/>
[[File:Passageway of the galleries within the walls of Tiryns.jpg|thumb|right|Part of the galleries within the walls of [[Tiryns]]]]
''[[Cyclopean masonry|Cyclopean]]'' is the term normally applied to the masonry characteristics of Mycenaean fortification systems and describes walls built of large, unworked boulders more than {{convert|8|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} thick and weighing several metric tonnes.<ref>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=78}}.</ref> They were roughly fitted together without the use of mortar or clay to bind them, though smaller hunks of limestone fill the interstices. Their placement formed a polygonal pattern giving the curtain wall an irregular but imposing appearance.<ref name=Fields11>{{harvnb|Fields|2004|p=11}}.</ref> At the top it would have been wide enough for a walkway with a narrow protective [[parapet]] on the outer edge and with hoop-like [[crenellations]].<ref name=Fields11/> The term ''Cyclopean'' was derived by the latter Greeks of the [[Classical Greece|Classical era]] who believed that only the mythical giants, the [[Cyclops|Cyclopes]], could have constructed such megalithic structures.<ref name=Fields10/> On the other hand, cut stone masonry is used only in and around gateways.<ref name=Fields11/> Another typical feature of Mycenaean megalithic construction was the use of a relieving triangle above a lintel block—an opening, often triangular, designed to reduce the weight over the lintel. The space was filled with some lighter stone.<ref name=Fields11/>
Cyclopean fortifications were typical of Mycenaean walls, especially at the citadels of Mycenae, Tiryns, [[Argos#Ancient|Argos]], [[Chrisso, Phocis#History|Crisa]] and Athens, while smaller boulders are found in [[Midea, Greece|Midea]] and large limestone slabs are found at Gla.<ref name=Fields11/> In the Mycenaean settlements found in [[Epirus]] and [[Cyprus]], Cyclopean-style walls are also present,<ref>{{harvnb|Tandy|2001|p=20}}: "In LH IBBB (ca. 1310-1190), Mycenaean material culture spread widely throughout coastal and inland Epirus; in this period Mycenaean engagement in Epirus was strongest, both quantitatively and qualitatively. Though the Kiperi tholos may have gone out of use early in LH IIIB, the Cyclopean wall found there, as well as those at Ephyra, Kastriza, and Ayia Eleni, cannot have been built (and probably after) LH IIIB."</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Iacovou|2013|p=610}}. Iacovou quotes Vassos Karageorghis who states that "The introduction of 'Cyclopean'-type walls at the very beginning of the LC IIIA period at Enkomi, Kition, Sinda and Maa-Palaeokastron was due to the arrival of Mycenaean settlers in Cyprus."</ref> as well as in western Anatolia.<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=127}}.</ref> Besides the citadels, isolated forts were also erected on various strategic locations. The fortification systems also incorporated technical refinements such as secret cisterns, galleries, sally ports and projecting bastions for the protection of gateways.<ref name=Fields10>{{harvnb|Fields|2004|p=10}}.</ref> On the other hand, the palace of Pylos, although a major center of power, paradoxically appears to have been left without any defensive walls.<ref>{{harvnb|Fields|2004|p=44}}.</ref>
===Other architectural features=== Mycenaean domestic architecture originates mainly from earlier Middle Helladic traditions (c. 2000–1650 BC) both in shape, as well as in location of settlement. The observed uniformity in domestic architecture came probably as a result of a shared past among the communities of the Greek mainland rather than as a consequence of cultural expansion of the Mycenaean Koine.<ref name=Kelder107>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=107}}.</ref> Moreover, varying sizes of mudbricks were used in the construction of buildings.<ref name="Kelder109"/>
Contrary to popular belief, some Mycenaean representative buildings already featured roofs made of fired tiles, as in [[Gla]] and [[Midea (Argolid)|Midea]].<ref>{{harvnb|Wikander|1990|p=288}}; {{harvnb|Shear|2000|p=134}}.</ref>
==Warfare== {{Main|Military of Mycenaean Greece}} The military nature of the Mycenaean Greeks is evident from the numerous weapons unearthed, the use of warrior and combat representations in contemporary art, and the preserved Greek [[Linear B]] records.<ref>{{harvnb|Cline|2012|p=305}}.</ref><ref name=Cline313>{{harvnb|Cline|2012|p=313}}.</ref> The Mycenaeans invested in the development of military infrastructure, with military production and logistics being supervised directly from the palatial centers.<ref name=Cline313/><ref>{{harvnb|Palaima|1999|pp=367–368}}.</ref> According to the Linear B records in the palace of [[Pylos]], every rural community (the ''damos'') was obliged to supply a certain number of men who had to serve in the army. Similar service was also performed by the aristocracy.<ref>{{harvnb|D'Amato|Salimbeti|2011|p=10}}.</ref>
[[File:Replicas of Mycenaean swords and cups.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.9|Replicas of Mycenaean swords and cups]] Mycenaean armies were initially based on heavy infantry, equipped with spears, large shields and in some occasion armor.<ref>{{harvnb|Howard|2011|p=7}}.</ref> Later in the 13th century BC, Mycenaean warfare underwent major changes both in tactics and weaponry and armed units became more uniform and flexible, while weapons became smaller and lighter.<ref name="Cline313"/> The spear remained the main weapon among Mycenaean warriors, while the sword played a secondary role in combat.<ref name=Howard50>{{harvnb|Howard|2011|p=50}}.</ref> Other offensive weapons used were bows, maces, axes, slings and javelins.<ref name=Howard50/><ref>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=306}}; {{harvnb|D'Amato|Salimbeti|2011|p=13}}.</ref> The precise role and contribution of [[war chariot|chariots]] on the battlefield is a matter of dispute due to the lack of sufficient evidence.<ref>{{harvnb|Howard|2011|p=63}}.</ref> It appears that chariots were initially used as fighting vehicles during the 16th to 14th centuries BC, while later, in the 13th century BC, their role was limited to battlefield transport.<ref>{{harvnb|Fields|2004|p=22}}.</ref>
The [[boar's tusk helmet]] was the most identifiable piece of Mycenaean armor in use from the beginning to the collapse of Mycenaean culture. It is also known from several depictions in contemporary art in Greece and the Mediterranean.<ref>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=119}}.</ref><ref name=Salimbeti23>{{harvnb|D'Amato|Salimbeti|2011|p=23}}.</ref> A representative piece of Mycenaean armor is the [[Dendra panoply]] (c. 1450–1400 BC) which consisted of a cuirass of a complete set of armor made up of several elements of bronze.<ref>{{harvnb|D'Amato|Salimbeti|2011|p=27}}.</ref> In general, most features of the later [[Hoplite#Equipment|hoplite panoply]] of classical Greek antiquity, were already known to Mycenaean Greece.<ref>{{harvnb|Kagan|Viggiano|2013|p=36: "In fact, most of the essential items of the "hoplite panoply" were known to Mycenaean Greece, including the metallic helmet and the single thrusting spear."}}</ref> "Figure-of-eight" shields were the most common type of Mycenaean shields.<ref>{{harvnb|D'Amato|Salimbeti|2011|p=20}}.</ref> During the Late Mycenaean period, smaller types of shields were adopted, either of completely circular shape, or almost circular with a part cut out from their lower edge.<ref>{{harvnb|Cline|2012|p=312}}; {{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=123}}.</ref>
==Art and craftwork==
===Vessels=== {{main|Mycenaean pottery}} [[File:Bull head rhyton Mycenae Grave IV, from Grave Circle A at Mycenae, 16th century BC (Archaeological Museum, Athens).jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|Silver repoussé [[rhyton]] with gold horns, from [[Grave Circle A, Mycenae|Grave Circle A]] at Mycenae, 16th century BC (Archaeological Museum, [[Athens]])]]
During the Late Mycenaean period (1400–1200 BC), Mycenaean vessels/pottery exhibited similarities spanning a significant area of the Eastern Mediterranean (i.e., from the Levant to Sicily) and possibly reflecting a form of economic and political union centered at Mycenae.<ref name=Castleden135>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=135}}.</ref> However, the pottery of Crete during this time remained distinct indicating a degree of autonomy on the island.<ref name=Castleden135/> The Mycenaean Greeks produced in large quantities a variety of diversely-styled vessels such as stirrup jars, large bowls, [[alabastron]], [[krater]] and stemmed cups (or [[kylix (drinking cup)|kylikes]]) resembling champagne glasses.<ref name=Castleden135/>
Stirrup jars (Linear B: ''ka-ra-re-u'', khlareus; "oil vessel"), specifically, were first invented on the island of Crete during the 16th century BC and used widely by the Mycenaeans from 1400 BC onward for transporting and storing wine and oil; the jars were usually pear-shaped or globular.<ref name=Castleden135/> As for stemmed cups (or kylikes), they evolved from Ephyraean goblets and a large quantity was discovered at a site called the "Potter's Shop" located in Zygouries.<ref name=Castleden135/> Mycenaean drinking vessels such as the stemmed cups contained single decorative motifs such as a [[Seashell|shell]], an [[octopus]] or a [[flower]] painted on the side facing away from the drinker.<ref name=Castleden135/> The Mycenaean Greeks also painted entire scenes (called "Pictorial Style") on their vessels depicting warriors, chariots, horses and deities reminiscent of events described in Homer's ''Iliad''.<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|pp=135–137: "Large kraters decorated in Pictorial Style are found almost exclusively in Cyprus, and for a long time it was naturally assumed that they were manufactured there, but a few examples have been found on the Greek mainland, mostly near Mycenae, and it has now been established that they were all manufactured at workshops close to Mycenae, probably at Berbati just to the east of the city, where there are the right clay sources. The ware was probably specifically made for export to Cyprus, where they were used as centerpieces for drinking ceremonies. The decoration appears to have been painted on at high speed and the effect is sometimes crude; Reynold Higgins calls it 'barbarous', which is a fair description, but the scenes showing warriors, horses and chariots can still tell us much about everyday life in Mycenaean Greece, and as much again about Mycenaean religious beliefs and mythology. One krater from Enkomi in Cyprus shows a charioteer with his groom riding along, perhaps into battle, while a long-robed god, Zeus perhaps, stands in his way holding the scales of destiny that will decide his fate. It is an archetypal scene reminiscent of several in the ''Iliad'', where the gods are shown intervening in battle and deciding the outcome."}}</ref> Other items developed by the Mycenaeans include clay lamps,<ref>{{harvnb|Furumark|1941|p=78: "There are two types of Mycenaean lamps. One of these (type 321) has a broad horizontal lip with two opposite depressions for wicks. This type is the clay version of a Minoan stone lamp, known in many examples both from Crete and from the Mainland. The other (type 321 a) has one wick-spout and a handle at the opposite side."}}</ref> as well as metallic vessels such as bronze tripod cauldrons (or basins).<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|pp=56, 166}}.</ref> A few examples of vessels in [[faience]] and [[ivory]] are also known.<ref>{{harvnb|Schofield|2006|p=107}}.</ref>
===Figures and figurines=== The Mycenaean period has not yielded sculpture of any great size. The statuary of the period consists for the most part of small terracotta figurines found at almost every Mycenaean site in mainland Greece—in tombs, in settlement debris, and occasionally in cult contexts (Tiryns, Agios Konstantinos on [[Methana]]). The majority of these figurines are female and anthropomorphic or zoomorphic. The female figurines can be subdivided into three groups which were popular at different periods: the earliest are the Phi-type, which look like the Greek letter phi and their arms give the upper body of the figurine a rounded shape. The Psi-type looks like the letter Greek psi: these have outstretched upraised arms. The latest (12th century BC) are the Tau-type: these figurines look like the Greek letter tau with folded(?) arms at right angles to the body. Most figurines wear a large 'polos' hat.<ref>{{harvnb|French|1971|pp=101–187}}</ref> They are painted with stripes or zigzags in the same manner as the contemporary pottery and presumably made by the same potters. Their purpose is uncertain, but they may have served as both votive objects and toys: some are found in children's graves but the vast majority of fragments are from domestic rubbish deposits.<ref>See account of their use in K.A. and Diana Wardle "The Child's Cache at Assiros, Macedonia", in Sally Crawford and Gillian Shepherd (eds): ''Children, Childhood and Society: Institute for Archaeology and Antiquity Interdisciplinary Studies (Volume I)'' Oxford: Archaeopress, 2007.</ref> The presence of many of these figurines on sites where worship took place in the Archaic and Classical periods (approximately 200 below the sanctuary of Athena at Delphi, others at the temple of [[Aphaea]] on Aegina, at the sanctuary of Apollo Maleatas above Epidauros and at Amyklae near Sparta), suggests both that many were indeed religious in nature, perhaps as votives, but also that later places of worship may well have first been used in the Mycenaean period.<ref>{{harvnb|Hägg|Marinatos|1981|loc=Robin Hägg, "Official and Popular Cults in Mycenaean Greece", pp. 35–39}}</ref>
Larger male, female or bovine terracotta wheelmade figures are much rarer. An important group was found in the Temple at Mycenae together with coiled clay snakes,<ref>{{harvnb|Moore|Taylour|French|1999}}</ref> while others have been found at Tiryns and in the East and West Shrines at Phylakopi on the island of Melos.<ref>{{harvnb|Renfrew|Mountjoy|Macfarlane|1985}}</ref>
===Frescoes=== [[File:Fresco of a Mycenaean woman, circa 1300 BC.jpg|thumb|right|upright=0.7|Fresco of a Mycenaean woman]]
The painting of the Mycenaean age was much influenced by that of the Minoan age. Fragments of wall paintings have been found in or around the palaces (Pylos, Mycenae, Tiryns) and in domestic contexts (Zygouries).<ref>{{harvnb|Immerwahr|1990}}.</ref> The largest complete wall painting depicting three female figures, probably goddesses, was found in the so-called "cult center" at Mycenae.<ref>{{harvnb|Taylour|1969|pp=91–97}}; {{harvnb|Taylour|1970|pp=270–280}}.</ref> Various themes are represented: hunting, [[Bull-leaping|bull leaping]] (tauromachy), battle scenes, processions, etc. Some scenes may be part of mythological narratives, but if so their meaning eludes us. Other frescoes include geometric or stylised motifs, also used on painted pottery (see above).
==Burial practices== The usual form of burial during this period was inhumation.<ref>{{harvnb|Cavanagh|Mee|1998}}.</ref> The earliest Mycenaean burials were mostly in individual graves in the form of a pit or a stone-lined [[cist]] and offerings were limited to pottery and occasional items of jewellery.<ref>{{harvnb|Taylour|French|Wardle|2007}}; {{harvnb|Alden|2000}}.</ref> Groups of pit or cist graves containing elite members of the community were sometimes covered by a tumulus (mound) in the manner established since the Middle Helladic.<ref>{{harvnb|Pelon|1976}}.</ref> It has been argued that this form dates back to the [[Kurgan culture]];<ref>{{harvnb|Hammond|1967|p=90}}.</ref> however, Mycenaean burials are in actuality an indigenous development of mainland Greece with the Shaft Graves housing native rulers.<ref>{{harvnb|Dickinson|1977|pp=33–34, 53, 59–60}}.</ref> Pit and cist graves remained in use for single burials throughout the Mycenaean period alongside more elaborate family graves.<ref>{{harvnb|Lewartowski|2000}}.</ref> The shaft graves at Mycenae within Grave Circles [[Grave Circle A, Mycenae|A]] and [[Grave Circle B, Mycenae|B]] belonging to the same period represent an alternative manner of grouping elite burials. Next to the deceased were found full sets of weapons, ornate staffs as well as gold and silver cups and other valuable objects which point to their social rank.<ref>{{harvnb|Dickinson|1977|pp=53, 107}}; {{harvnb|Anthony|2007|p=48}}.</ref>
{{double image|right|Treasury of Atreus, 13th century BC royal tholos tomb near Mycenae-exterior.jpg|200|Treasury of Atreus, 13th century BC royal tholos tomb near Mycenae-interior.jpg|200|[[Treasury of Atreus]], 13th century BC royal tholos tomb near Mycenae: exterior (left) and interior (right) view.}}
Beginning also in the Late Helladic period are to be seen communal tombs of rectangular form. Nevertheless, it is difficult to establish whether the different forms of burial represent a social hierarchization, as was formerly thought, with the [[Beehive tomb|"tholos"]] being the tombs of the elite rulers, the individual tombs those of the leisure class, and the communal tombs those of the people. Cremations increased in number over the course of the period, becoming quite numerous in the last phase of the Mycenaean era.<ref>{{harvnb|Papadimitriou|2001}}.</ref> The tholos was introduced during the early 15th century as the new and more imposing form of elite burial.<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=97}}.</ref> The most impressive tombs of the Mycenaean era are the monumental royal tombs of Mycenae, undoubtedly intended for the royal family of the city. The most famous is the [[Treasury of Atreus]], a [[Beehive tomb|tholos]]. A total of nine of such tholos tombs are found in the region of Mycenae, while six of them belong to a single period (Late Helladic IIa, c. 1400-1300 BC).<ref>{{harvnb|Kelder|2010|p=95}}.</ref> It has been argued that different dynasties or factions may have competed through conspicuous burial.<ref>{{harvnb|Graziado|1991|pp=403–440}}.</ref>
==Writing== {{main|Linear B}} [[File:Linear B (Mycenaean Greek) NAMA Tablette 7671.jpg|thumb|Linear B tablets (Mycenaean Greek)]] In circa 1600 BC, the Mycenaean Greeks borrowed from the [[Minoan civilization]] its syllabic writing system (i.e., [[Linear A]]) and developed their own [[syllabic script]] known as [[Linear B]].<ref name=Britannica>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/topic/Linear-A|title=Linear A and Linear B|work=Encyclopædia Britannica|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.|accessdate=3 March 2016}}</ref> The Linear B script was utilized by the Mycenaean palaces in Greece for administrative purposes where economic transactions were recorded on clay tablets and some pottery in the [[Mycenaean Greek|Mycenaean dialect]] of the [[Greek language]].<ref name=Britannica/> The Linear B tablets were first discovered in [[Crete]] by English archaeologist [[Sir Arthur Evans]] c. 1900 and later deciphered by English architect and cryptographer [[Michael Ventris]] in 1952.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/biography/Arthur-Evans|title=Sir Arthur Evans|work=Encyclopædia Britannica|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.|accessdate=3 March 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/biography/Michael-Ventris|title=Michael Ventris|work=Encyclopædia Britannica|publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc.|accessdate=3 March 2016}}</ref> Ventris's discovery of an archaic Greek dialect in the Linear B tablets demonstrated that Mycenaean Greek was "the oldest known Greek dialect, elements of which survived in Homer’s language as a result of a long oral tradition of epic poetry."<ref name=Britannica/>
==Legacy== In the 8th century BC, after the end of the so-called [[Greek Dark Ages]], Greece emerged with a network of myths and legends, the greatest of all being that of the Trojan [[Epic Cycle]].<ref name=Castleden2>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=2}}.</ref> In general, the [[Greeks]] of classical antiquity idealized the Mycenaean period as a glorious period of heroes, closeness of the gods and material wealth.<ref>{{harvnb|Hansen|2004|p=7}}.</ref> The legends of [[Homeric epics|Homer's Epics]] were especially and generally accepted as part of the Greek past and it was not until the 19th century that scholars began to question Homer's historicity.<ref name=Castleden2/> At this time, German archaeologist [[Heinrich Schliemann]] undertook the first modern archaeological excavations in Greece at the site of [[Mycenae]] in 1876.<ref>{{harvnb|Sansone|2004|loc="Greece in the Bronze Age", pp. 7–8}}.</ref> Thus, Schliemann set out to prove the historical accuracy of the ''Iliad'' by identifying the places described by Homer.<ref name=Castleden2/>
As part of the Mycenaean heritage that survived, the names of the gods and goddesses of Mycenaean Greece became major figures of the [[Twelve Olympians|Olympian Pantheon]] of later antiquity.<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=235}}.</ref> Moreover, the language of the Mycenaeans offers the first written evidence of [[Greek language|Greek]],<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=228}}.</ref> while a significant part of the Mycenaean vocabulary can also be found in modern English.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Vallance|first1=Richard|title=Did you Know you Speak Mycenaean Greek? You do!|url=https://www.academia.edu/12633620|website=academia.edu|date=2015|accessdate=30 March 2016|quote=Whether we realize it or not, not only are tens of thousands of English words direct derivatives of ancient Greek, but some are derived even from Mycenaean Greek, which makes them very ancient indeed!}}</ref>
The Mycenaean Greeks were also pioneers in the field of [[engineering]], launching large-scale projects unmatched in Europe until the [[Roman architecture|Roman period]], such as fortifications, bridges, culverts, aqueducts, dams and roads suitable for wheeled traffic. They also made several architectural innovations, such as the [[Discharging arch#History|relieving triangle]].<ref name=Castleden231>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=231}}</ref> They were also responsible for transmitting a wide range of arts and crafts, especially of Minoan origin. The Mycenaean civilization was in general more advanced compared to the Late Bronze Age cultures of the rest of Europe.<ref>{{harvnb|Castleden|2005|p=230}}.</ref> Several Mycenaean attributes and achievements were borrowed or held in high regard in later periods; so, it would be no exaggeration to consider Mycenaean Greece as a cradle of civilization.<ref name=Castleden231/>

'''Narrative history''' is the practice of writing [[history]] in a story-based form. It tends to entail history-writing based on reconstructing series of short-term events, and since the influential work of [[Leopold von Ranke]] on professionalising history-writing in the nineteenth century has been associated with [[empiricism]]. The term ''narrative history'' thus overlaps with the term ''histoire événementielle'' ('event-history') coined by [[Fernand Braudel]] in the early twentieth century, as he promoted forms of history-writing analysing much longer-term trends (what he called the ''[[longue durée]]'').<ref>''A Dictionary of Cultural and Critical Theory'', ed. by Michael Payne and Jessica Rae Barbera, 2nd edn (Chichester: Wiley-Blackwell, 2013), s.v. 'Braudel, Fernand' (p. 90).</ref>
Though history is considered a social science, the story-based nature of history allows for the inclusion of a greater or lesser degree of narration in addition to an analytical or interpretative exposition of historical knowledge. It can be divided into two subgenres: the traditional narrative and the modern narrative.
'''Traditional narrative''' focuses on the chronological order of history. It is event driven and tends to center upon individuals, action, and intention. For example, in regard to the [[French Revolution]], a historian who works with the traditional narrative might be more interested in the revolution as a single entity (one revolution), centre it in [[Paris]], and rely heavily upon major figures such as [[Maximilien Robespierre]].
Conversely, '''modern narrative''' typically focuses on structures and general trends. A modern narrative would break from rigid chronology if the historian felt it explained the concept better. In terms of the French Revolution, a historian working with the modern narrative might show general traits that were shared by revolutionaries across [[France]] but would also illustrate regional variations from those general trends (many confluent revolutions). Also this type of historian might use different sociological factors to show why different types of people supported the general revolution.
Historians who use the modern narrative might say that the traditional narrative focuses too much on what happened and not enough on why and causation. Also, that this form of narrative reduces history into neat boxes and thereby does an injustice to history. [[J H Hexter]] characterized such historians as "lumpers". In an essay on [[Christopher Hill (historian)|Christopher Hill]], he remarked that "lumpers do not like accidents: they would prefer them vanish...The lumping historian wants to put all of the past into boxes..and then to tie all the boxes together into one nice shapely bundle."
Historians who use traditional narrative might say that the modern narrative overburdens the reader with trivial data that had no significant effect on the progression of history. They believe that the historian needs to stress what is consequential in history, as otherwise the reader might believe that minor trivial events were more important than they were.
